Title: The Guardian Frogs of Borneo
Subtitle: Why Exceptions Matter in Biology and Everyday Life
SponsoredBy: - [Johana Goyes Vallejos, PhD](https://jogoyesvallejos.weebly.com/) — Postdoc in the Division of Biological Sciences, University of Missouri – Columbia

overview.Text:
#### Driving Question(s):
- Across animal species, is there truth to the stereotype that males are “competitive,” while females are “caring”, or is this an oversimplification?
- Are the smooth guardian frogs of Borneo the first known species of frog with “competitive females” and “caring males”?
#### Essential Question(s):
- How can we use scientific methods to identify a general pattern?
- Why do exceptions matter in science and in life?
#### Learning Summary:
Out of 8,000+ frog species, Guardian Frogs are one of the first to show females that call & males that care for offspring. Students will gain wonder and appreciation for how diverse animal mating systems are while doing fun activities and analyzing real data.
#### Hooks
- Part 1: Highly interactive card-based activity that simulates data collection + amazing animal videos
- Part 2: Atmospheric videos of Borneo, first person narrative of an early career Latina scientist + use of authentic data
overview.Description:
This lesson puts students in the role of scientists, collecting and analyzing real data to answer questions. In Part 1, students "collect" data through a card-based activity called "Role With It." Briefly, students get a male or female card of 1 out of 12 species. When their card is called, students introduce it with a "song" and dance that match the attributes of the species it represents. The class then records data on sexual signal exaggeration and parental investment for that species. 

Once they have collected all 24 specimens (cards) students analyze this data (for Part 2) to generate a general observation: "across nonhuman animal species, females tend to be more caring (contributing more parental investment), while males tend to be more adapted to attracting and competing for mates." These are known as *conventional sex roles.* Students then identify *sex-role-reversed species,* such as jacanas (a bird) and guardian frogs, which have "caring males" and "competitive females".

Part 3 lets students use real data to test whether the Smooth Guardian Frog (*Limnonectes palavenensis*) is truly the first known sex-role-reversed frog species, with "caring males" and "competitive females". The lesson begins with an atmospheric video that immerses students in the sights, sounds, and mysteries of the island of Borneo. Students are then given a brief introduction to the geography of the region and learn that Borneo is claimed by three Asian countries (Malaysia, Indonesia and Brunei). The rest of the lesson focuses on Dr. Johana Goyes Vallejos' research in the forests of Brunei. Students test hypotheses by synthesizing information and analyzing a scatter plot to determine that this fascinating species is indeed the first frog known to have "caring males" and "competitive females." 

The lesson offers a wide variety of opportunities for student movement, collaboration, creativity, and active engagement.

preview.QuickPrep:
1. Check out lesson multimedia below
2. Look over <AnchorLink href="#teaching_materials"> Teaching Materials </AnchorLink>
3. Read our easy <AnchorLink href="#procedure"> Procedure </AnchorLink>
4. Teach it and <AnchorLink href="#feedback"> let us know what you think! </AnchorLink>

Multimedia.title: Trailer: I Like That!
Multimedia.lessonRelevance: Trailer giving an overview of what this lesson entails.

Multimedia.title: I Like That! How our eyes and brains interact to determine what we like and dislike
Multimedia.description: This video explores how things we see (visual stimuli) affect emotional states and interact with our memories and higher order thinking (cognition) to produce preferences and behavior. This basic framework is adapted from human and animal behavior research. We use this framework throughout the middle school-targeted lesson below. In the lesson, students perform an experiment to understand their own preferences and dive into research on fish, exploring how sensitivity to different frequencies of light affects mate preferences. We dive into this topic in detail in our second video supporting this lesson.
Multimedia.lessonRelevance: This video sets up key vocabulary and concepts we will use throughout this lesson. It sets up activities that will have students trying to understand how emotion, memory, and higher-order connections explain their own preferences for certain images.

Multimedia.title: Images for Part 1 Experiment
Multimedia.lessonRelevance: Students will rank these images based on their arbitrary preferences. They will then conduct an experiment to try to understand why they ranked things as they did.

Multimedia.title: How we see color - Colm Kelleher
Multimedia.lessonRelevance: For Part 2, this video gives a nice explanation of what color is: different wavelengths of light reflected from objects and detected by our eyes and brain.

Multimedia.title: The Science of Color Perception
Multimedia.lessonRelevance: For Part 2, this neat video adds a bit more detail about color perception. (Only a short clip is embedded in presentation 2). We carried the "cones" characters into our original video (next in the playlist).

Multimedia.title: How do we know what a fish likes? (And can we predict it?)
Multimedia.lessonRelevance: Supports Part 2 activities analyzing real scientific data to follow in the footsteps of Drs. Tamra Mendelson and Tory Williams. Explains basics of how color vision works, contrasted against freshwater fish called darters which are used in the research covered here.

Multimedia.title: Creature Stats Character Sheets
Multimedia.lessonRelevance: In Part 3, students apply what they've learned about visual processing in the brain to artworks. They will use these original character sheet designs to calculate proportions and test whether being outside the range of human variation makes a character inherently creepy or cute.

Multimedia.title: Darter facts: the colorful little fish | Animal Fact Files
Multimedia.lessonRelevance: More Details on Darters (for Part 2). Supplement–not included in any lesson materials.

links.linkText: Download G5-6 Materials for All Parts

1.title: Why Do I Like That?
1.preface: Students conduct an experiment on themselves. They rank images and attempt to understand *why* they preferred some images over others.

2.title: The Perception of Beauty
2.preface: Students analyze real data to determine if fish mating preferences are explained by sensitivity to certain colors.

3.title: Creature Stats
3.preface: Students collect data from original artworks to test whether being outside the range of human variation makes a drawing creepy or cute.

1.title: Why Do I Like That?
1.preface: Students conduct an experiment on themselves. They rank images and attempt to understand *why* they preferred some images over others.

links.linkText: Download G7-8 Materials for All Parts

3.title: Creature Stats
3.preface: Students collect data from original artworks to test whether being outside the range of human variation makes a drawing creepy or cute.

partPrep.PrepQuickDescription: Cut out class set of image cards (1 per group of ~2)
partPrep.PrepDetails:
Have students do one of the following:
- Read [this article](https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/more-recycling-wont-solve-plastic-pollution/)
- [Watch this video ](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iO3SA4YyEYU)

steps.StepQuickDescription: What question are we investigating?
steps.StepDetails: Students interpret a series of images (rebus puzzle) to determine the focus of this lesson. Their answers are recorded on the "I Like That" Part 1 worksheet.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Quick refresher of the scientific method
steps.StepDetails: This lesson is a real experiment and the results are specific to each class that completes it. This is exactly what scientists face in their own labs when they ask questions that don't have answers yet. Because this requires students to have a solid understanding of the Scientific Method, the first part of the lesson is a recap of each step in that process.

steps.StepQuickDescription: The Image Cards present a set of ten images to the students which they must rank from favorite (#1) to least favorite (#10) on their worksheet (Qs 1-10).
steps.StepDetails: Students have five minutes to complete this activity. Their observations form the basis for the next part of the scientific method. Students need either digital or printed copies of Images A - J (Image Cards) as well as the "I Like That" Part 1 Worksheet.
steps.TeachingTips: Try to save the Image Cards and laminate them or put them in protective sleeves if you plan to teach the lesson multiple times to save on printed paper.

steps.StepQuickDescription: The next step after collecting observations is questioning why they are the way they are.
steps.StepDetails: By talking about visual stimuli, students understand why they ranked the 10 images the way they did. [▶ Trailer: I Like That!](https://youtu.be/QnoVSKx4G1c) explores how the eyes and brain interact to result in our visual preferences.
steps.Vocab: - **stimulus:** something that causes an organ or tissue (like your brain) to react (plural is stimuli)

steps.StepQuickDescription: Students next consider how the interface among Cognition, Perception, and Emotion of visual stimuli influenced their observations.
steps.StepDetails: Check In: After watching the video and learning more about the Cognition, Perception, and Emotion triad, students answer Questions 11-15 on their worksheets about decision making and how it is influenced by these things.
steps.Vocab:
- **cognition:** how well you understand what you're perceiving
- **perception:** our ability to see, hear, or become aware of a stimulus through our senses
- **emotion:** a positive or negative feelings brought about by chemicals released in the brain
- **preference:** whether you like or dislike something which is influenced by a combination of cognition, perception, and emotions

steps.StepTitle: Developing Hypotheses and Setting Up Experiments
steps.StepQuickDescription: The next step in the scientific method is to develop a hypothesis that can be tested which gets at the "Why."
steps.StepDetails: The class tests the hypothesis that cognition and emotion determine how the images were ranked.

steps.StepQuickDescription: To determine whether the hypothesis can be rejected or accepted with confidence, the group sets up an experiment.
steps.StepDetails: The experiment must try to isolate two of the three effects (Cognition and Emotion) and measure how much each contributes to preference.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Think - Pair
steps.StepDetails: Using descriptive numerical scales, students discuss in pairs (or small groups) how they would rate their top-ranked images based on Emotion and Cognition.
steps.TeachingTips: Throughout the lesson, you will occasionally see *Think - Ink - Pair - Share*, or some combination thereof, on the presentation slides. The words not grayed out are the goals for that activity. *Think* means a student considers a question or challenge on their own, *Ink* indicates they should be writing their thoughts or answers down, *Pair* asks that once they have completed Think and/or Ink, students pair up (or get in small groups) and talk about the question or activity. Lastly, *Share* is when the class comes together and talks about the question or activity as a group.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Think - Ink - Pair
steps.StepDetails: Students learn how to develop predictions related to their hypothesis and experimental design by looking at example data. They have two minutes to think about the example presented to them and decide which responses they would predict. Students then discuss their answers in pairs or small groups.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Adopting a prediction.
steps.StepDetails: Once the class understands how to formulate a prediction, for the purposes of this study they adopt the following Prediction (P1): Top ranked images will have high cognitive and emotional scores.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Working in pairs, students trade off being the "scientist" and "test-subject."
steps.StepDetails: The student acting as the "scientist" shows the "test subject" one image at a time and asks questions using the Cognitive and Emotion Score scales to collect data. Each pair has 10 minutes to complete the experiment, then they switch roles and repeat the process. The scientist should record the test subject's data on the test subject's worksheet (page 4).

steps.StepQuickDescription: Using the data from the experiment, students plot their results on graphs.
steps.StepDetails: Students plot their data to make similar graphs as the ones used in the example data to practice making predictions. These graphs plot Emotion vs. Cognitive scores for the top and bottom five scores.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Based on the class's data, what can be concluded about how cognition and emotion affect how images are ranked?
steps.StepDetails: Students answer questions 9 - 15 on their worksheets. The class can also discuss as a group the results, why they may have ended up with the results that were observed, and how the experimental design may have affected any outcomes.

parts.partPreface: Students conduct an experiment on themselves. They rank images and attempt to understand *why* they preferred some images over others.

partPrep.PrepQuickDescription:
1. Look over the slides
2. Print out handouts

steps.StepQuickDescription: How many ladybugs are there?
steps.StepDetails: Students see a set of squares and are tasked with counting how many ladybugs they see. This activity was developed by experimental psychologist, Akiyoshi Kitaoka, who studies visual illusions.

steps.StepQuickDescription: What patterns could be observed?
steps.StepDetails: Students recall their data from Part 1 from the image ranking experiment and whether about whether they noticed any patterns.
steps.Vocab: - **aesthetics:** a set of principles concerned with the nature and appreciation of beauty, especially in art.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Organizing and identifying sensory information.
steps.Vocab: - **perception:** the ability to see, hear, and become aware of something through the senses.

steps.StepQuickDescription: How does the human eye work?
steps.StepDetails: The perception of beauty is often influenced by colors which is perceived using our eyes. Students learn more about how this process works in the interface between the eyes and brain.

steps.StepQuickDescription: An introduction to Dr. Mendelson's work with Darters.
steps.StepDetails: Darters are great model organisms to study evolutionary changes in animal communication over time.
steps.Vocab: - **model organism:** a non-human species used to study some biological phenomena or process to provide insight into how the phenomena or process works in other species.

steps.StepQuickDescription: What a fish likes
steps.StepDetails: Students watch [▶ The Science of Color Perception](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=poL7nDmqjmk) which explains more about Dr. Mendelson's work on how fish preference is studied scientifically.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Think - Ink - Pair - Share
steps.StepDetails: Using actual data from Dr. Mendelson's studies, students consider how visual stimuli and fish perception interact to influence fish preferences (Q3 in the worksheet). They then learn about box plots and how they are used in data analysis.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Students reflect on their findings. This work can be done in class or for homework.
steps.TeachingTips: The beginning of Part 3 will include time to discuss take-homes from the analysis. Specifically, which is more important--cognition or emotion--for explaining students' ranked preferences for images?

parts.partPreface: Students analyze real data to determine if fish mating preferences are explained by sensitivity to certain colors.

partPrep.PrepQuickDescription:
1. Look over the slides
2. Print out handouts
partPrep.PrepTeachingTips: You might have assign a reading from the Part 2 "Going Further" section for homework.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Quick write-up about how to define cute vs. creepy.
steps.StepDetails: Students write briefly about how they might define something as being cute and creepy. They then look at a line-up of characters and write about which one they find the cutest vs. creepiest and why.

steps.StepQuickDescription: What do we mean when something is called "typical"?
steps.StepDetails: After learning about what typicality means, students apply it to how it can influence preference through our different sensory systems.
steps.Vocab: - **typicality:** within certain limits of what is typical, or occurs most often

steps.StepQuickDescription: How does "atypicality" influence our preferences?
steps.StepDetails: While "typical" things often reflect what we prefer, on the other hand atypical things can cause us to feel repulsed or uneasy. Students use animated characters to dig deeper into this.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Form a prediction
steps.StepDetails: Students answer Q1-3 on their worksheet to form a prediction about how we percieve what is cute vs. creepy.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Evaluate the characters
steps.StepDetails: There are seven illustrated characters which have several different measurements for different parts of their bodies. Students use these to calculate different proportions, or ratios, between different body parts, such as eye height to eye width, by finishing Table 1 in the worksheet (Qs4-15). Lastly students mark the ratios on a pre-made histogram (Q16).
steps.TeachingTips: Try to save the Creature Stats Character Sheets and laminate them or put them in protective sleeves if you plan to teach the lesson multiple times to save on printed paper.

steps.StepQuickDescription: What is a histogram?
steps.StepDetails: Students go through an example of what a histogram is and how to interpret the data to draw conclusions.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Understanding the data
steps.StepDetails: Dot plots use similar data to histograms, but make display the data in a way that's a little easier to understand. Students practice looking at example dot plots and analyzing them for information.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Drawing conclusions about cute vs. creepy.
steps.StepDetails: Using the histogram data from Creature Stats, students draw final conclusions about how something could be labeled as cute or creepy based on ratios.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Do the data support the predictions?
steps.StepDetails: Students refer back to their predictions and discuss whether the data they collected and analyzed support them.

gatheredVocab.definition: how well you understand what you're perceiving
our ability to see, hear, or become aware of a stimulus through our senses
a positive or negative feelings brought about by chemicals released in the brain
whether you like or dislike something which is influenced by a combination of cognition, perception, and emotions
a set of principles concerned with the nature and appreciation of beauty, especially in art.
a non-human species used to study some biological phenomena or process to provide insight into how the phenomena or process works in other species.
within certain limits of what is typical, or occurs most often

background.Content:
#### Connection to Research
 Instead of telling students that a pattern exists, we have them discover it for themselves. That is, rather than telling them, "In animal species with *conventional sex roles,* males invest more in attracting and competing for mates, while females invest more in parental care," we have students collect data in a fun, interactive format and draw this conclusion from the data. They are then more invested in understanding cases of *sex role reversed species* that are the exceptions to this rule, and have "caring males" and "competitive females." 

In part 2, students follow in the footsteps of an early career Latina scientist, Dr. Johana Goyes Vallejos, testing the same hypotheses she did during her PhD research. Students analyze a real graph and table she collected on the island of Borneo to determine if the Smooth Guardian Frog (*Limnonectes palavanensis*) is the first sex-role-reversed frog species known to science. (It is!) 
#### Research Background
 Watch [ERROR: CHECK *{vid3}* REFERENCE. NO LINK FOUND]() to get a nice summary of Dr. Johana Goyes Vallejos’ scientific journey.

While pursuing a PhD in ecology and evolutionary biology at the University of Connecticut, Johana heard about a poorly studied frog called the Smooth Guardian Frog (*Limnonectes palavanensis*), found only on the island of Borneo in Southeast Asia. In a couple of scientific papers in the 1980s, a researcher had described a highly unusual behavior--the males guard eggs hidden under the leaf litter (thus, the common name of the species). When the eggs hatch, the male then carries the tadpoles (on his back!) to small pools of water where they can develop into adult frogs.
Johana, who was deeply interested in parental care behavior decided to fly to the tiny sultanate of Brunei (ruled by a sultan, rather than a king) and learn about this frog herself. She established a study population, tracking individuals and recording audio of frog calls, often on her own at night, wading through thick mud and fording streams. During her observations, she noticed a tiny peep. It sounded very different from the male calls she had been used to hearing. After careful observation, she confirmed that indeed, these were female calls, which had never been described before by anyone. (See [▶ How we see color - Colm Kelleher](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l8_fZPHasdo))

Out of 8,000+ known frog species, Johana had found one of only a couple that are known to have calling females. Previously, scientists had thought females might be physiologically incapable of producing calls. In contrast, when she started focusing on female calling behavior, she found that they were actually calling *more* than males! Students will recapitulate this finding by analyzing a figure showing male and female calling rates.

As [Borneo is now being heavily deforested](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deforestation_in_Borneo), populations of Guardian Frogs are declining. In the final assignment, students are asked to synthesize everything they’ve learned to write a persuasive paragraph about why these exceptional frogs matter and what we stand to lose if they are lost. 

#### Researcher Bio
Dr. Johana Goyes Vallejos is a Preparing Future Faculty for Faculty Diversity Postdoctoral Fellow in the Division of Biological Sciences at the University of Missouri, Columbia. She graduated with a B.Sc. in Biology with a minor in Genetics from the Universidad del Valle in Cali, Colombia. She received her Ph.D. in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology from the
University of Connecticut, studying mating systems, parental care behavior, and acoustic
communication in frogs. Her research has taken her to many tropical forests across the
world, including Panama, Costa Rica, Guyana, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei
Darussalam. 

At the University of Missouri, Dr. Goyes Vallejos continues her research on
mating behavior and parental care strategies using frogs with elaborate parental behaviors
as study systems. In addition, since 2018, she serves as a research mentor for an NSF-
funded Research Experience for Undergraduates program in Costa Rica, providing
hands-on training in animal behavior and field research to undergraduate students
belonging to minoritized groups in STEM. She is passionate about sharing her research findings with scientific and non-scientific audiences through various media outlets. When not chasing frogs in remote forests around the world Dr. Goyes Vallejos enjoys salsa dancing, storytelling and crocheting amigurumis. 

[Learn more about Johana at her website](https://jogoyesvallejos.weebly.com/)

#### Further Reading and Listening
- [The Shape of The World Podcast: When the girl frog sings](https://shapeoftheworldshow.com/2019/05/04/episode-10-when-the-girl-frog-sings/) (May 2019)
- [FrogLife.org| Female communication in anurans: duets, ultrasonic calls and sex-role reversal](http://www.froglife.org/2019/08/29/croaking-science-female-communication-in-anurans-duets-ultrasonic-calls-and-sex-role-reversal/) (August 2019)
- [National Geographic España| Los padrazos del mundo de los anfibios](https://www.nationalgeographic.com.es/ciencia/grandes-reportajes/padrazos-mundo-anfibios_13763) (March 2019)
- [The New York Times| ​Devoted Dads of the Amphibian World](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/04/science/frogs-parenting-reproduction.html) (December 2018)
- [KU Today| Extraordinary 'faithful father' revealed by study of smooth guardian frog of Borneo](https://today.ku.edu/2018/12/13/research-smooth-guardian-frog-borneo-details-extraordinary-faithful-father) (December 2018)
- [Science Magazine: These female frogs are the first of their kind to croon to their guys](http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/06/these-female-frogs-are-first-their-kind-croon-their-guys)​ (June 2017)
- [Science & Vie| Chez la grenouille de Bornéo, c'est madame qui chante](https://www.science-et-vie.com/nature-et-enviro/chez-la-grenouille-de-borneo-c-est-madame-qui-chante-8925) (June 2017)

#### Related Scientific Paper
![Screenshot of scientific journal article](https://catalog.galacticpolymath.com/lessons/TEST/goyespaper.png)
[Link to study](https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0%2C43&q=Calling+behavior+of+males+and+females+of+a+Bornean+frog+with+male+parental+care+and+possible+sex-role+reversal&btnG=)

learning-chart.Title: About the GP Learning Chart
learning-chart.Description:
This Galactic Polymath Learning Chart illustrates the areas of knowledge covered. This lesson targets Science, but it helps teach national learning standards in 4 subjects: 
- [Common Core Math](http://www.corestandards.org/Math/); [Common Core ELA](http://www.corestandards.org/ELA-Literacy/); [Next Generation Science (NGSS)](https://www.nextgenscience.org/); and [College, Career, and Civic Life (C3) Social Studies Standards](https://www.socialstudies.org/standards/c3).
In total, there are 18 standards across US grade band(s): 9-12, 5-6, 7-8.

standards.LearningObj:
1. Explain how animal behavior facilitates survival and reproduction.
2. Collect, reorganize, and analyze data to identify a pattern (that males tend to have adaptations to compete for mates, while females provide more parental care), and interpret exceptions to that pattern.
3. Learn to test hypotheses by interpreting authentic scientific graphs and data.
4. Understand that there is always variability in scientific data.
5. Cite evidence to support explanatory claims.
6. Integrate multiple lines of evidence to explain why biological exceptions matter to science and society.

dimensions.name: Algebra, Geometry, Trig, Calculus & Higher Level Thinking

standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - In P1&2, students analyze the data they collect in the interactive "Role with It" activity. In P3 they interpret a real scientific figure to test the hypothesis that Guardian frogs are a sex-role-reversed species.

standardsGroup.statements: Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects of extreme data points (outliers).
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students interpret differences (in an authentic scientific graph) between male and female frog calling patterns to test a hypothesis.

standardsGroup.statements: Interpret information presented in diverse media and formats (e.g., visually, quantitatively, orally) and explain how it contributes to a topic, text, or issue under study.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students interpret differences (in an authentic scientific graph) between male and female frog calling patterns to test a hypothesis.

standardsGroup.statements: Integrate visual information (e.g., in charts, graphs, photographs, videos, or maps) with other information in print and digital texts.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - In P1-P2, students will combine data they collect into tables and interpret their findings to identify a pattern. In P3, they will use data provided in a table to label missing text in a graph; then interpret the graph and explain how it supports the finding that Guardian frogs are a sex-role-reversed species.

standardsGroup.statements: Translate quantitative or technical information expressed in words in a text into visual form (e.g., a table or chart) and translate information expressed visually or mathematically (e.g., in an equation) into words.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - In P1-P2, students will combine data they collect into tables and interpret their findings to identify a pattern. In P3, they will use data provided in a table to label missing text in a graph; then interpret the graph and explain how it supports the finding that Guardian frogs are a sex-role-reversed species.

standardsGroup.statements: Analyze and interpret data to provide evidence for phenomena.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - In P1-P2, students will combine data they collect into tables and interpret their findings to identify a pattern. In P3, they will use data provided in a table to label missing text in a graph; then interpret the graph and explain how it supports the finding that Guardian frogs are a sex-role-reversed species.

standardsGroup.statements: Ask questions that arise from careful observation of phenomena, models, or unexpected results, to clarify and/or seek additional information.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will practice looking at real data that is variable, and become familiar with looking at mean and variability, through experience plotting boxplots and follow-up interpretation of data and discussion.

standardsGroup.statements: Apply concepts of statistics and probability (including mean, median, mode, and variability) to analyze and characterize data, using digital tools when feasible.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students calculate proportions of males and females of our sample of species. They use these statistics to derive a general pattern and identify exceptional species that buck the trend.

standardsGroup.statements: Apply scientific reasoning, theory, and/or models to link evidence to the claims to assess the extent to which the reasoning and data support the explanation or conclusion.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students interpret differences (in an authentic scientific graph) between male and female frog calling patterns to test a hypothesis.

standardsGroup.statements: Ask questions that arise from careful observation of phenomena, or unexpected results, to clarify and/or seek additional information.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - In P2, students are asked to identify surprising patterns and to explain which species they would study and why. This requires them to deeply understand the data they've collected.

standardsGroup.statements: Apply concepts of statistics and probability (including determining function fits to data, slope, intercept, and correlation coefficient for linear fits) to scientific and engineering questions and problems, using digital tools when feasible.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students interpret differences (in an authentic scientific graph) between male and female frog calling patterns to test a hypothesis.

standardsGroup.statements: Patterns can be used to identify cause-and-effect relationships.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students interpret differences (in an authentic scientific graph) between male and female frog calling patterns to test a hypothesis.

standardsGroup.statements: Empirical evidence is needed to identify patterns.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students interpret differences (in an authentic scientific graph) between male and female frog calling patterns to test a hypothesis.

standardsGroup.statements: The traits that positively affect survival are more likely to be reproduced, and thus are more common in the population.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - This standard is not explicitly addressed, but can easily be connected by asking students to explain how some of the behaviors covered in the lesson should be favored by selection (i.e. how they increase survival and/or reproduction of individuals who behave that way, compared to those who do not).

dimensions.name: Evaluating Sources, Communicating Conclusions & Taking Action

standardsGroup.statements: Construct arguments using claims and evidence from multiple sources, while acknowledging the strengths and limitations of the arguments.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - In P1-P2, students interpret data they collect and organize in a table. In P3, they synthesize multiple lines of evidence to determine whether Guardian frogs are a sex-role-reversed species and argue for why they should be studied further.

standardsGroup.statements: Animals engage in characteristic behaviors that increase the odds of reproduction.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will explore a wide variety of animal mate attraction and parental behaviors that increase the odds of survival and reproduction and reflect on both the general pattern of "caring females, competitive males" and exceptions to this pattern.

standardsGroup.statements: Apply scientific ideas, principles, and/or evidence to construct, revise and/or use an explanation for real-world phenomena, examples, or events.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will integrate data visualization of real biological data and scientific text, using scientific ideas and principles to investigate an real example of exceptions to the rule in nature, with evidence for sex role reversal in Guardian Frogs.

standardsGroup.statements: Graphs, charts, and images can be used to identify patterns in data.
standardsGroup.alignmentNotes: - Students will practice looking at real data that is variable, and become familiar with looking at mean and variability, through interpreting data represented in tables and scatter plots.

feedback.Content:
### Please let us know how it went with your class! 
Share your feedback in < 5 min with these forms:
- [For teachers](https://forms.gle/bZeaTqPEedQMjMV59)
- [For students](https://forms.gle/YnBorosBjWQHobgX7)

credits.Content:
#### Lead Author and Creative Director:
Matt Wilkins, PhD  
If you liked this lesson, please help spread the word! Feel free to tag me ([@mattwilkinsbio](https://twitter.com/mattwilkinsbio)) and GP ([@galacticPM](https://twitter.com/galacticPM)) on Twitter with your experiences and student questions! 

And please [sign up for our mailing list](https://galacticpolymath.us8.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=42413c3d307f9b69fd5d5319e&id=33924ebd91) to hear what’s coming up next!

#### Sponsor and Producer
[Johana Goyes Vallejos, PhD](https://jogoyesvallejos.weebly.com/)

#### "Role with It" Animal Diversity Cards Illustrator
[Anna Wilkins](https://www.annamationvisdev.com)

records.name: Rachel Neurath, PhD
records.title: Soil Microbial Ecologist | STEM Educator | Writer
